paragraph: CHAPTER I. THE OLD HOUSE.
tokens: old

paragraph: "Somewhat back from the village street     Stands the old-fashioned country seat."
tokens: village street stand old fashioned country seat

paragraph: Once upon a time in an old town, in an old street, there stood a very old house. Such a house as you could hardly find nowadays, however you searched, for it belonged to a gone-by time--a time now quite passed away.
tokens: time old town old street stand old house house find search belong gone time time pass

paragraph: It stood in a street, but yet it was not like a town house, for though the front opened right on to the pavement, the back windows looked out upon a beautiful, quaintly terraced garden, with old trees growing so thick and close together that in summer it was like living on the edge of a forest to be near them; and even in winter the web of their interlaced branches hid all clear view behind.
tokens: stand street town house front open pavement back window look beautiful terrace garden old tree grow thick close summer live edge forest winter web interlace branch hide clear view

paragraph: There was a colony of rooks in this old garden. Year after year they held their parliaments and cawed and chattered and fussed; year after year they built their nests and hatched their eggs; year after year, I _suppose_, the old ones gradually died off and the young ones took their place, though, but for knowing this _must_ be so, no one would have suspected it, for to all appearance the rooks were always the same--ever and always the same.
tokens: be colony rook old garden year year hold parliament caw chatter fuss year year build nest hatch egg year year _suppose old one die young one take place know _must_ suspect appearance rook same same

paragraph: Time indeed seemed to stand still in and all about the old house, as if it and the people who inhabited it had got _so_ old that they could not get any older, and had outlived the possibility of change.
tokens: time seem stand old house person inhabit get old get old outlive possibility change

paragraph: But one day at last there did come a change. Late in the dusk of an autumn afternoon a carriage drove up to the door of the old house, came rattling over the stones with a sudden noisy clatter that sounded quite impertinent, startling the rooks just as they were composing themselves to rest, and setting them all wondering what could be the matter.
tokens: day last come change dusk autumn afternoon carriage drive door old house come rattling stone sudden noisy clatter sound impertinent startling rook compose rest set wonder matter

paragraph: A little girl was the matter! A little girl in a grey merino frock and grey beaver bonnet, grey tippet and grey gloves--all grey together, even to her eyes, all except her round rosy face and bright brown hair. Her name even was rather grey, for it was Griselda.
tokens: little girl matter little girl grey merino frock grey beaver bonnet grey tippet grey glove grey eye round rosy face bright brown hair name grey

paragraph: A gentleman lifted her out of the carriage and disappeared with her into the house, and later that same evening the gentleman came out of the house and got into the carriage which had come back for him again, and drove away. That was all that the rooks saw of the change that had come to the old house. Shall we go inside to see more?
tokens: gentleman lift carriage disappear house same evening gentleman come house get carriage come drive rook see change come old house go see more

paragraph: Up the shallow, wide, old-fashioned staircase, past the wainscoted walls, dark and shining like a mirror, down a long narrow passage with many doors, which but for their gleaming brass handles one would not have known were there, the oldest of the three old servants led little Griselda, so tired and sleepy that her supper had been left almost untasted, to the room prepared for her. It was a queer room, for everything in the house was queer; but in the dancing light of the fire burning brightly in the tiled grate, it looked cheerful enough.
tokens: shallow wide old fashioned staircase wainscot wall dark shine mirror long narrow passage many door gleam brass handle know old old servant lead little tired sleepy supper leave untasted room prepare queer room house queer dancing light fire burn tile grate look cheerful

paragraph: "I am glad there's a fire," said the child. "Will it keep alight till the morning, do you think?"

paragraph: The old servant shook her head.
tokens: old servant shake head

paragraph: "'Twould not be safe to leave it so that it would burn till morning," she said. "When you are in bed and asleep, little missie, you won't want the fire. Bed's the warmest place."
tokens: safe leave burn morning say bed asleep little missie want fire bed warmest place

paragraph: "It isn't for that I want it," said Griselda; "it's for the light I like it. This house all looks so dark to me, and yet there seem to be lights hidden in the walls too, they shine so."

paragraph: The old servant smiled.
tokens: old servant smile

paragraph: "It will all seem strange to you, no doubt," she said; "but you'll get to like it, missie. 'Tis a _good_ old house, and those that know best love it well."

paragraph: "Whom do you mean?" said Griselda. "Do you mean my great-aunts?"

paragraph: "Ah, yes, and others beside," replied the old woman. "The rooks love it well, and others beside. Did you ever hear tell of the 'good people,' missie, over the sea where you come from?"

paragraph: "Fairies, do you mean?" cried Griselda, her eyes sparkling. "Of course I've _heard_ of them, but I never saw any. Did you ever?"

paragraph: "I couldn't say," answered the old woman.

paragraph: "My mind is not young like yours, missie, and there are times when strange memories come back to me as of sights and sounds in a dream. I am too old to see and hear as I once could. We are all old here, missie. 'Twas time something young came to the old house again."

paragraph: "How strange and queer everything seems!" thought Griselda, as she got into bed. "I don't feel as if I belonged to it a bit. And they are all _so_ old; perhaps they won't like having a child among them?"

paragraph: The very same thought that had occurred to the rooks! They could not decide as to the fors and againsts at all, so they settled to put it to the vote the next morning, and in the meantime they and Griselda all went to sleep.
tokens: same thought occur rook decide for settle put vote next morning meantime go sleep

paragraph: I never heard if _they_ slept well that night; after such unusual excitement it was hardly to be expected they would. But Griselda, being a little girl and not a rook, was so tired that two minutes after she had tucked herself up in bed she was quite sound asleep, and did not wake for several hours.
tokens: hear sleep night such unusual excitement expect little girl rook tired minute tuck bed sound asleep wake several hour

paragraph: "I wonder what it will all look like in the morning," was her last waking thought. "If it was summer now, or spring, I shouldn't mind--there would always be something nice to do then."
tokens: wonder look morning last wake thought summer spring mind be nice do

paragraph: As sometimes happens, when she woke again, very early in the morning, long before it was light, her thoughts went straight on with the same subject.
tokens: happen wake morning light thought go same subject

paragraph: "If it was summer now, or spring," she repeated to herself, just as if she had not been asleep at all--like the man who fell into a trance for a hundred years just as he was saying "it is bitt--" and when he woke up again finished the sentence as if nothing had happened--"erly cold." "If only it was spring," thought Griselda.
tokens: summer spring repeat asleep man fall trance year say bitt wake finish sentence happen cold spring think

paragraph: Just as she had got so far in her thoughts, she gave a great start. What was it she heard? Could her wish have come true? Was this fairyland indeed that she had got to, where one only needs to _wish_, for it to _be_? She rubbed her eyes, but it was too dark to see; _that_ was not very fairyland-like, but her ears she felt certain had not deceived her: she was quite, quite sure that she had heard the cuckoo!
tokens: get thought give great start hear wish come true fairyland get need _wish rub eye dark see fairyland ear feel certain deceive sure hear cuckoo

paragraph: She listened with all her might, but she did not hear it again. Could it, after all, have been fancy? She grew sleepy at last, and was just dropping off when--yes, there it was again, as clear and distinct as possible--"Cuckoo, cuckoo, cuckoo!" three, four, _five_ times, then perfect silence as before.
tokens: listen hear fancy grow sleepy last drop be clear distinct possible cuckoo cuckoo _five_ time perfect silence

paragraph: "What a funny cuckoo," said Griselda to herself. "I could almost fancy it was in the house. I wonder if my great-aunts have a tame cuckoo in a cage? I don't _think_ I ever heard of such a thing, but this is such a queer house; everything seems different in it--perhaps they have a tame cuckoo. I'll ask them in the morning. It's very nice to hear, whatever it is."
tokens: funny cuckoo say fancy house wonder great aunt have tame cuckoo cage _think hear thing queer house seem different have tame cuckoo ask morning nice hear

paragraph: And, with a pleasant feeling of companionship, a sense that she was not the only living creature awake in this dark world, Griselda lay listening, contentedly enough, for the sweet, fresh notes of the cuckoo's friendly greeting. But before it sounded again through the silent house she was once more fast asleep. And this time she slept till daylight had found its way into all but the _very_ darkest nooks and crannies of the ancient dwelling.
tokens: pleasant feeling companionship sense only living creature awake dark world lay listen sweet fresh note cuckoo friendly greeting sound silent house fast asleep time sleep daylight find way _very_ dark nook cranny ancient dwelling

paragraph: She dressed herself carefully, for she had been warned that her aunts loved neatness and precision; she fastened each button of her grey frock, and tied down her hair as smooth as such a brown tangle _could_ be tied down; and, absorbed with these weighty cares, she forgot all about the cuckoo for the time. It was not till she was sitting at breakfast with her aunts that she remembered it, or rather was reminded of it, by some little remark that was made about the friendly robins on the terrace walk outside.
tokens: dress warn aunt love neatness precision fasten button grey frock tie hair smooth brown tangle _could_ tie absorb weighty care forget cuckoo time sit breakfast aunt remember remind little remark make friendly robin terrace walk

paragraph: "Oh, aunt," she exclaimed, stopping short half-way the journey to her mouth of a spoonful of bread and milk, "have you got a cuckoo in a cage?"

paragraph: "A cuckoo in a cage," repeated her elder aunt, Miss Grizzel; "what is the child talking about?"

paragraph: "There is a cuckoo somewhere in the house," said Griselda; "I heard it in the night. It couldn't have been out-of-doors, could it? It would be too cold."

paragraph: "We have a cuckoo, my dear, though it isn't in a cage, and it isn't exactly the sort of cuckoo you are thinking of. It lives in a clock."

paragraph: "Why not?" said Miss Grizzel.

paragraph: "I knew a little girl once," pursued Miss Grizzel, "who was quite of opinion the cuckoo _was_ alive, and nothing would have persuaded her it was not. Finish your breakfast, my dear, and then if you like you shall come with me and see the cuckoo for yourself."

paragraph: "Thank you, Aunt Grizzel," said Griselda, going on with her bread and milk.

paragraph: "Yes," said Miss Tabitha, "you shall see the cuckoo for yourself."

paragraph: "Thank you, Aunt Tabitha," said Griselda. It was rather a bother to have always to say "thank you," or "no, thank you," twice, but Griselda thought it was polite to do so, as Aunt Tabitha always repeated everything that Aunt Grizzel said. It wouldn't have mattered so much if Aunt Tabitha had said it _at once_ after Miss Grizzel, but as she generally made a little pause between, it was sometimes rather awkward. But of course it was better to say "thank you" or "no, thank you" twice over than to hurt Aunt Tabitha's feelings.
tokens: thank say bother have say thank thank think polite do repeat say matter say once_ make little pause awkward course good say thank thank hurt feeling

paragraph: After breakfast Aunt Grizzel was as good as her word. She took Griselda through several of the rooms in the house, pointing out all the curiosities, and telling all the histories of the rooms and their contents; and Griselda liked to listen, only in every room they came to, she wondered _when_ they would get to the room where lived the cuckoo.
tokens: breakfast good word take several room house point curiosity tell history room content like listen room come wonder get room live cuckoo

paragraph: Aunt Tabitha did not come with them, for she was rather rheumatic. On the whole, Griselda was not sorry. It would have taken such a _very_ long time, you see, to have had all the histories twice over, and possibly, if Griselda had got tired, she might have forgotten about the "thank you's" or "no, thank you's" twice over.
tokens: come rheumatic whole sorry take _very_ long time see have history get tired forget thank thank

paragraph: The old house looked quite as queer and quaint by daylight as it had seemed the evening before; almost more so indeed, for the view from the windows added to the sweet, odd "old-fashionedness" of everything.

paragraph: "My pot-pourri," she explained.

paragraph: They were just then standing in what she called the "great saloon," a handsome old room, furnished with gold-and-white chairs, that must once have been brilliant, and faded yellow damask hangings. A feeling of awe had crept over Griselda as they entered this ancient drawing-room. What grand parties there must have been in it long ago! But as for dancing in it _now_--dancing, or laughing, or chattering--such a thing was quite impossible to imagine!
tokens: stand call great saloon handsome old room furnish gold white chair brilliant fade yellow damask hanging feeling awe creep enter ancient draw room grand party dancing _now_ dancing laugh chatter thing impossible imagine

paragraph: Miss Grizzel crossed the room to where stood in one corner a marvellous Chinese cabinet, all black and gold and carving. It was made in the shape of a temple, or a palace--Griselda was not sure which. Any way, it was very delicious and wonderful. At the door stood, one on each side, two solemn mandarins; or, to speak more correctly, perhaps I should say, a mandarin and his wife, for the right-hand figure was evidently intended to be a lady.

paragraph: Miss Grizzel gently touched their heads. Forthwith, to Griselda's astonishment, they began solemnly to nod.

paragraph: "Oh, how do you make them do that, Aunt Grizzel?" she exclaimed.

paragraph: "It is on the stroke of ten," said Miss Grizzel, consulting her watch; "now, my dear, you shall make acquaintance with our cuckoo."

paragraph: The cuckoo "that lived in a clock!" Griselda gazed round her eagerly. Where was the clock? She could see nothing in the least like one, only up on the wall in one corner was what looked like a miniature house, of dark brown carved wood. It was not so _very_ like a house, but it certainly had a roof--a roof with deep projecting eaves; and, looking closer, yes, it _was_ a clock, after all, only the figures, which had once been gilt, had grown dim with age, like everything else, and the hands at a little distance were hardly to be distinguished from the face.
tokens: cuckoo live clock gaze clock see least wall corner look miniature house dark brown carve wood house have roof roof deep project eave look close clock figure gilt grow dim age else hand little distance distinguish face

paragraph: Miss Grizzel stood perfectly still, looking up at the clock; Griselda beside her, in breathless expectation. Presently there came a sort of distant rumbling. _Something_ was going to happen. Suddenly two little doors above the clock face, which Griselda had not known were there, sprang open with a burst and out flew a cuckoo, flapped his wings, and uttered his pretty cry, "Cuckoo! cuckoo! cuckoo!" Miss Grizzel counted aloud, "Seven, eight, nine, ten." "Yes, he never makes a mistake," she added triumphantly. "All these long years I have never known him wrong. There are no such clocks made nowadays, I can assure you, my dear."
tokens: stand look clock breathless expectation come sort distant rumbling go happen little door clock face know spring open burst fly cuckoo flapp wing utter pretty cry cuckoo cuckoo cuckoo count make mistake add long year know wrong be such clock make assure dear

paragraph: "But _is_ it a clock? Isn't he alive?" exclaimed Griselda. "He looked at me and nodded his head, before he flapped his wings and went in to his house again--he did indeed, aunt," she said earnestly; "just like saying, 'How do you do?' to me."
tokens: clock alive exclaim look nod head flapp wing go house aunt say say do

paragraph: Again Miss Grizzel smiled, the same odd yet pleased smile that Griselda had seen on her face at breakfast. "Just what Sybilla used to say," she murmured. "Well, my dear," she added aloud, "it is quite right he _should_ say, 'How do you do?' to you. It is the first time he has seen _you_, though many a year ago he knew your dear grandmother, and your father, too, when he was a little boy. You will find him a good friend, and one that can teach you many lessons."

paragraph: "What, Aunt Grizzel?" inquired Griselda, looking puzzled.

paragraph: "May I come to see the cuckoo--to watch for him coming out, sometimes?" asked Griselda, who felt as if she could spend all day looking up at the clock, watching for her little friend's appearance.

paragraph: So saying, Miss Grizzel opened a second door in the little ante-room, and, to Griselda's surprise, at the foot of a short flight of stairs through another door, half open, she caught sight of her Aunt Tabitha, knitting quietly by the fire, in the room in which they had breakfasted.
